course.subject: COMP
course.name: Cloud Computing and Big Data Systems
course.description: Big data systems, including Cloud Computing and parallel data processing frameworks, emerge as enabling technologies in managing and mining the massive amount of data across hundreds or even thousands of commodity servers in datacenters. This course exposes students to both the theory and hands-on experience of this new technology. The course will cover the following topics. (1) Basic concepts of Cloud Computing and production Cloud services; (2) MapReduce - the de facto datacenter-scale programming abstraction - and its open source implementation of Hadoop. (3) Apache Spark - a new generation parallel processing framework - and its infrastructure, programming model, cluster deployment, tuning and debugging, as well as a number of specialized data processing systems built on top of Spark. By walking through a number of hands-on labs and assignments, students are expected to gain first-hand experience programming on real world clusters in production datacenters.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2011 OR COMP 2012H

reviews.author: Juhyeon Park
reviews.title: Overall good course
reviews.comment_content:
Topic
1 - Logistics, Cloud concept and characteristics
2 - Cloud fundamentals and Service models
3 - Virtualization
4 - Cloud Storage Systems
5 - MapReduce I
6 - Hadoop
7 - MapReduce Algorithm Design
8 - RDD and Spark
9 - Spark Programming I
10 - Spark Programming II
11 - Graph Analytics
12 - Container Orchestration & Kubernetes
13 - Serverless Computing

Overall contents are well-informed and not hard to follow.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor has good pronunciation so there was not any difficulty to understand what he said; he sometimes explains the things with daily examples, it was really helpful for understanding. However, the quality of lab classes are bad which were taught by TAs. I basically did not understand more than half of the content of some lab classes and even some TAs just show ppt slides without any coding examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
-Homework and labs (30%)
Most assignments are based on programming languages such as Java, Python, SQL and etc, but it would not be that harsh if you had taken any basic courses of programming; there's a lot of sample codes on assignment file, so just need some applications of it. The difficulty of assignment is not that bad, is manageable.

-Programming on Amazon EC2 and locally hosted VMs
Open-ended course project (20%)
Dr. WANG provides numerous options for this project and one of them is free topic. You need to form the group before the midterm commences, so you'd better to find your members ASAP. The grading of the project is not that strict, just need some application of what we have learned so far.

-Final exam (50%)
The worst part of this course. The exam was almost 2 hours long but all the questions require long answers with specific reasons and 40% of the exam encloses coding questions which are really time consuming. It would be really helpful if you are able to get past papers to prepare the final. The average of Final exam was 54.18.
reviews.comment_workload: In this course, you have to figure things out by yourself like many COMP courses. (Use google to find the way to solve). Workload is pretty light compared to other 4000's courses in UST. If you know how to do the assignments, it will be just a piece of cake. Some assignments need coding explaining presentation so you would better to understand what you wrote on the screen.

reviews.author: _Daniel
reviews.title: Not worth learning
reviews.comment_content:
The course gives an introduction to Cloud Computing. You will learn about the various Cloud providers, how to use AWS, Spark, Hadoop, HDFS, MapReduce, etc.

IMHO, the course is not too interesting. But if you absolutely adore Big Data and Cloud, you might enjoy the course.

Many points discussed about in the lecture notes aren't thorough enough, and require more researching online to understand completely.

Python 2 was used. And due to the quick changes in this area, newer features of the tools aren't explained.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The accent of the instructor is quite hard to decipher and requires some effort in listening. He pronounces English words like how they "would have sounded on paper", e.g. "cached" as "ke-shed" like in Shakespearean English. He also has a strong Mandarin accent. I have misheard some words from him and didn't notice until some times later.

His thought process isn't quite easy to understand since his sentences don't really follow the: topic => elaboration => conclusion structure. So it's quite hard to grasp some points of what he wanted to say. It's more like a listening exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade consists of assignments, a group project and the final exam.

The final take home exam took me ~12hrs to complete.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments are too easy and there isn't any feeling of accomplishment after completing them.

The group project took us some time to complete and there were quite some points we didn't understanding after picking our topic of reimplementing "Serverless functions" in open sourced tools in Kubernetes, OpenFAAS, and etc.

reviews.author: GK
reviews.title: Big Data, useful but difficult
reviews.comment_content:
Big data should be very useful in the future. Content include what is big data and tools analyzing big data.
The focus should be on the tools, including hadoop and spark. Both requires strong programming skills. The tools are difficult to understand especially if you are not from computer science. Unless you are taking the minor for big data, do not take this course.
Project is very free and about any big data system or you create one. Idea and adequate execution are more important than having a super hard project. Also, most group can get full mark so it is not that important after all.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor tried his best to demonstrate the materials and tools. However, it is quite difficult to understand. Furthermore, the speed is quite fast. Overall, his notes are organized, but you have to focus and jot notes or most of his notes will not be understandable.
Lab are quite useful in understanding lecture materials.
reviews.comment_grading: No midterm, 5 assignments, 1 project and final exam. Scores are given at a relatively loose way so everyone gets high score. However, grade are given very badly. Since all scores are published, median is C+. That means over half of the class get C range. Two failed. It is definitely not a good grade course.
reviews.comment_workload:
You will always hear the professor emphasizing on the heavy workload of the course. If you have no knowledge on big data tools, you will have to spend much time understanding the course materials. They are really tough to understand.
But no midterm reduced the workload in the middle of the term.

reviews.author: bryanaa
reviews.title: An introductory course for big data junkies
reviews.comment_content: Big data systems, including Cloud Computing and parallel data processing frameworks, emerge as enabling technologies in managing and mining the massive amount of data across hundreds or even thousands of commodity servers in datacenters. This course exposes students to both the theory and hands-on experience of this new technology. The course will cover the following topics. (1) Basic concepts of Cloud Computing and production Cloud services; (2) MapReduce - the de facto datacenter-scale programming abstraction - and its open source implementation of Hadoop. (3) Apache Spark - a new generation parallel processing framework - and its infrastructure, programming model, cluster deployment, tuning and debugging, as well as a number of specialized data processing systems built on top of Spark. By walking through a number of hands-on labs and assignments, students are expected to gain first-hand experience programming on real world clusters in production datacenters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is a mainland guy, U of Toronto grad. I think this is his first time teaching a UG course.

Overall great guy: great teaching, explains various concepts really well, responds to emails real fast, and MEMES in lecture notes (I am not joking).

The only downside I think is his accent which is a little bit difficult for me to comprehend.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
- Homework and lab: 30%
- Course project: 25%
- Final exam: 45%

Homework and lab: full mark, course project: 24/25, final exam: 35.78 / 45 (avg: 27.3)
Final grade: A+

Overall: good grade, 25% of the class got A range
reviews.comment_workload:
For a level 4 CS course,  the workload of this course is okay-ish

Workload:
- 5 programming assignments
- Labs (not every week)
- 1 course project
- 1 Final exam

reviews.author: bakso goreng
reviews.comment_content:
The course will cover the following topics.
(1) Basic concepts of Cloud Computing and production Cloud services;
(2) MapReduce - the de facto datacenter-scale programming abstraction - and its open source implementation of Hadoop.
(3) Apache Spark - a new generation parallel processing framework - and its infrastructure, programming model, cluster deployment, tuning and debugging, as well as a number of specialized data processing systems built on top of Spark.
reviews.comment_teaching: Great storytelling including history of cloud computing and explaining system design decisions for Hadoop, Spark, MapReduce, etc..
reviews.comment_workload:
4 assignments
1 project
1 final

Assignment 1 on using AWS services, particularly running, managing EC2 instance.
Assignment 2 heaviest on using MapReduce for WordCount, Relative Frequencies, both using PairofStrings and Stripes data structure.
Assignments 3 and 4 on Spark can be found from online sources.

Final project is open-ended

reviews.author: howardfo
reviews.comment_content: The course start with same basic topics related to cloud and infrastructure. Then some MapReduce concept and algorithm are taught with use of python2 and spark. Finally, covering some extra topic like serverless programming and future development of cloud service.
reviews.comment_teaching: Most of the time the lecturer explain the contents with the bunch of pictures and conceptual diagram. Not much hand-on experience on cloud and serverless programming is taught.
reviews.comment_workload:
Adequate.
You need to submit assignment through github classroom.
The level of assignment is easy and you may refer to different sources for reference.

reviews.author: cdbn
reviews.comment_content:
